title: 106_hr752
content: The "Airline Passenger Fairness Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings of the Act are also outlined. The Congress finds that the number of airline passengers on US carriers is expected to increase to 1 billion by 2008. The number of certified large air carriers has decreased, with 6 major carriers forming 3 large networks dominating 70% of the domestic market. Only 2/3 of communities with scheduled air service in 1978 still have it today. The Department of Transportation's report in 1997 highlighted 75 city pairs with fare increases of 30% or more, leading to a decrease in traffic by over 20%. Only half of the communities with scheduled air service in 1978 still have it today, mostly served by smaller airlines feeding hub airports. The 1997 Fares Consumer Report identified 75 city pairs with fare increases of 30% or more, resulting in a traffic decrease of over 20%. A 1998 Department of Transportation study revealed that major US air carriers charge double at hub airports without low fare competition compared to those with low fare competitors. The General Accounting Office found fares to be 12% to 71% higher at hubs dominated by one carrier or consortium. The General Accounting Office found that fares are significantly higher at hub airports dominated by one carrier or consortium. Complaints about airline travel have increased by over 25% from the previous year, with a notable rise in complaints against large US air carriers. Complaints against large United States air carriers increased from 6,394 in 1997 to 7,994 in 1998. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission reported a worsening delay problem in flights, with a 20% increase in daily aircraft delays of 15 minutes or longer in 1996 compared to 1995. The Commission also forecasted a 52% increase in domestic and international passenger enplanements between 1996 and 2006. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission forecasted a 52 percent increase in domestic and international passenger enplanements between 1996 and 2006. A 1998 Department of Transportation study found that large US air carriers charge about 60 percent more for passengers traveling to or from small communities compared to those traveling between large communities. The Congress has directed the Secretary of Transportation to prohibit unfair and deceptive practices in the airline industry, particularly focusing on the large United States air carriers charging about 60 percent more for passengers traveling to or from small communities compared to those traveling between large communities. SEC. 3. FAIR PRACTICES FOR AIRLINE PASSENGERS. Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as informing passengers about oversold flights and allowing confirmed reserved passengers to board. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code now includes specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as informing passengers about oversold flights and allowing confirmed reserved passengers to use portions of their ticket for travel. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code now includes specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as delivering checked baggage within 24 hours, providing full access to fares, and giving notice to passengers with confirmed reserved space on flights. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code now includes specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as delivering checked baggage within 24 hours, providing full access to fares, giving notice to passengers with confirmed reserved space on flights, accurately informing passengers of flight delays, cancellations, or diversions, and refunding the full purchase price of unused tickets within 48 hours of purchase upon request. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code now includes practices for certificated air carriers, such as providing information to enable informed decisions about frequent flyer programs, including seat availability and redemption success rates. The Secretary is required to report on this information. The Secretary must report on the number of redeemable seats and redemption success rates for certificated air carriers. Violations of these requirements will be included in the Department of Transportation's monthly Air Travel Consumer Report. The term 'confirmed reserved space' refers to a verified seat on a specific date, flight, and class of service requested by a passenger. The term 'confirmed reserved space' means a seat on a specific date, flight, and class of service requested by a passenger and verified by the carrier.
